0.text: Holofernes and Nathaniel discuss Don Armado, with whom Nathaniel has been conversing. They mock his inferior intellect, criticizing his pronunciation and saying that they abhor 'such rackers of orthography' . Armado, Moth, and Costard enter; Armado tells the learned men that the King has asked him to prepare 'some delightful ostentation, or show, or pageant, or antick or firework'  to entertain the Princess and her party. He asks Holofernes and Nathaniel for their help in planning this entertainment, and Holofernes suggests that they present a show of the Nine Worthies. The men discuss who will play the roles of the Worthies, with Holofernes saying that he will play three of the roles himself. They then go off to plan their show.

2.text: Holofernes and Nathanaël discuss Don Armado, with whom Nathanaël has had conversations. They mock him for his inferior intellect, criticizing his pronunciation and saying they abhor 'such ravishing ravishers of orthography'. Armado, Moth, and Costard enter; Armado tells the learned men that he has been commissioned by the King to prepare 'some delicious spectacle, or spectacle, or pageant, or antechamber, or fireworks' to amuse the Princess and her company. He asks for the help of Holofernes and Nathanaël in planning this diversion, and Holofernes suggests that they present a representation of the Nine Worthies. The men discuss who will play the roles of the Worthies, Holofernes saying that he will play three of the roles himself. They then depart to plan their spectacle.

0.text: Jim and the Harling children feel the happiest and most content that spring just playing in the garden. They do not yet know that the summer will change everything. In the beginning of summer, some Italians come into town and set up a dancing pavilion in a vacant lot. They begin giving dancing lessons to children, and people start to gather and congregate around the lot. Now there is something for people to do and somewhere for them to socialize. Dancing becomes a city-wide craze, and every Saturday night there is a late-night dance. Jim goes all the time, as do many girls and boys from the country. At this point, Antonia, Lena, and Tiny become known as 'the hired girls' and are always at the dances too.

2.text: Jim and the Harling children feel the greatest joy and satisfaction simply playing in the garden during the spring. They are not yet aware that the summer will bring about everything to change. At the beginning of the summer, the Italians arrive in town and set up a dance pavilion on a vacant lot. They start giving dance lessons to the children, and people begin to gather and congregate around the lot. Now, there is something for people to do and a place for them to socialize. Dance becomes the latest fashion in town, and every Saturday night, there is a late dance. Jim always goes, as do many girls and boys from the countryside. At this point, Antonia, Lena, and Tiny become known as 'the engaged girls' and are always present at the dances.

4.text: Jim and the Harling children feel the greatest happiness and the greatest satisfaction in simply playing in the garden during the spring. They are not yet aware that summer will bring a change. At the beginning of summer, the Italians arrive in town and set up a dance establishment on a vacant lot. They start giving dance lessons to the children, and people begin to gather and congregate around the lot. Now, there's something for people to do and a place for them to gather. Dance becomes the latest fashion in town, and every Saturday night, there's a late dance. Jim always goes, just like many of the country girls and boys. At this stage, Antonia, Lena, and Tiny become known as the 'fiancée girls' and are always present at the dances.

0.text: Elizabeth reads through Darcy's letter with a mixture of emotions. When she first reads Darcy's explanation of his conduct with Bingley and Jane, she dismisses his explanation of his concern about Jane's indifference as false, and believes he acted solely because of her family. However, when she begins reading his explanation of the dealings with Wickham, she begins to read more clearly. She soon begins to realize that she had not known anything of Wickham before the night when he told her of he and Darcy, and she wonders why she didn't realize his impropriety at speaking of such things to a stranger. As she continues to reread and think, she realizes that she had been 'blind, partial, prejudiced, absurd,' and that she believes Darcy's version of what happened. She then rereads the section about Jane and Bingley, and sees that she cannot deny the justice of his description of Jane's seeming indifference after all. After two hours of wandering in the park she returns home to be told that both Fitzwilliam and Darcy had come to say their good-byes

2.text: Elizabeth read Darcy's letters with a mix of emotions. When she first read his explanation of his behavior towards Bingley and Jane, she rejected his explanation as false, believing he was acting solely out of family loyalty, and that his concerns about Jane's indifference were unfounded. However, as she began to read his explanation of the affair with Wickham, she started to read it with greater clarity. Soon, she began to realize that she knew very little about Wickham before the night he spoke to her about him and Darcy, and she wondered why she hadn't realized how inappropriate it was for him to discuss such things with a stranger. As she continued to re-read and reflect, she realized she had been 'blind, biased, prejudiced, absurd,' and that she now believed Darcy's version of events. She then re-read the section on Jane and Bingley, and saw that she couldn't deny the justice of his description of Jane's apparent indifference. After a two-hour walk in the park, she returned home to be informed that Mr. Fitzwilliam and Mr. Darcy had come to wish her a safe journey.

She then re-read the section on Jane and Bingley, and saw she couldn't deny the justice of his description of Jane's apparent indifference. After a two-hour walk in the park, she returned home to be told that Messrs. Fitzwilliam and Darcy had come to wish her a good journey.

At first, when she had read them, she had rejected his explanation of his behavior towards Bingley and Jane as false, thinking that he had acted solely out of family loyalty and that his concerns about Jane's indifference were unfounded. However, as she read his explanation of the affair with Wickham, she began to read it with growing clarity. Soon, she began to realize that she knew almost nothing about Wickham before the night when he had a conversation with Darcy, and she began to wonder why she hadn't realized at the time that it was inappropriate for him to discuss such things with a stranger. Continuing to re-read and reflect, she realized that she had been 'blind, prejudiced, misjudged, absurd' and that she now believed Darcy's version of events. She re-read the section on Jane and Bingley, and saw that she could not deny the justice of his description of Jane's apparent indifference. After a two-hour walk in the park, she returned home to be informed that Mr. Fitzwilliam and Darcy had come to wish her a safe journey.

0.text: Cunegonde tells her story to Candide: Bulgar soldiers attack and kill her family and rape her. While Cunegonde fights off her attacker, a captain comes in and, enraged at the officer's disrespect, kills him. He then takes Cunegonde as a prisoner of war. The captain keeps Cunegonde as his servant for three months and then sells her to a Jewish businessman. The businessman shares her services with the same Inquisitor who ordered the execution of Pangloss and flogging of Candide. Cunegonde wards off the sexual advances of both men. Cunegonde attends the post-earthquake execution and recognizes Candide. Cunegonde's story ends. Back in the present, Candide and Cunegonde eat dinner together and hang out until one of her owners, the businessman Don Issachar, comes to get her.

2.text: Cunégonde recounts her story to Candide: Bulgarian soldiers attack and brutally kill her family. While Cunégonde defends herself against her attacker, a captain intervenes and, outraged by the officer's insolence, kills him. He then takes Cunégonde hostage. The captain keeps Cunégonde as a servant for three months before selling her to a Jewish merchant. The merchant shares her services with the same inquisitor who ordered the execution of Pangloss and the flogging of Candide. Cunégonde rebuffs the amorous advances of these two men. Cunégonde witnesses the post-earthquake executions and recognizes Candide. Cunégonde's story comes to an end. Returning to the present, Candide and Cunégonde dine together and spend time until one of her owners, the merchant Don Issachar, comes to take her away.

0.text: Jane and Rochester have a quiet wedding three days after that. Diana and Mary are happy for her and say they will come to visit. St. John did not reply to the letter Jane sent to him regarding the wedding; however, he has since maintained a correspondence with her. Jane goes to see Adele and changes her school for a better and closer one. Jane then tells the reader that it has been ten years now that she has been married as she sits to write about her life. She and Rochester are always together, and after two years, he had regained sight in one of his eyes, enough to see his first-born son. Diana and Mary are both married and come to visit Jane, and she visits them. St. John went to India and is still there. He remained unmarried, and Jane relates that he feels that he will soon die and join God

2.text: Jane and Rochester get married in an intimate ceremony three days later. Diana and Mary are happy for her and say they will come to visit her. John does not respond to the letter Jane sent him about her marriage, however, he has continued to write to her since. Jane goes to visit Adele and changes schools to a better and closer one. Jane then tells the reader that it has been ten years since she got married while she sits down to write her story. She and Rochester are still together, and two years later, he regains sight in one of his eyes, enough to see their firstborn. Diana and Mary are both married and come to visit her, and she visits them in return. John has gone to India and is still there. He has remained a bachelor, and Jane specifies that he thinks he will soon die and join God.

4.text: Jane and Rochester get married in an intimate ceremony three days later. Diana and Mary are happy for her and say they will come to visit her. John does not respond to the letter Jane sent him to talk about her marriage, but he continues to write to her. Jane goes to visit Adele and changes schools for a better and closer one. Jane then tells the reader that it has already been ten years since her marriage, while she sits down to write her story. She and Rochester are still together, and two years later, he regains his sight in one of his eyes, enough to see their firstborn. Diana and Mary are both married and come to visit her, and she visits them in turn. John has gone to India and is still there. He remains single, and Jane clarifies that he thinks he will soon die and join God.
